title: E2E: Docker/Podman authentication blocks container builds
description:
**Issue**: podman-compose and docker compose both fail to build E2E test containers due to corporate credential helper (ddtool) attempting to authenticate to vault.us1.ddbuild.io

**Error**: 
```
[ddtool] retrieving identity jwt: context deadline exceeded
Error: error getting credentials - err: exit status 1
```

**Impact**: Cannot run E2E tests in containerized environment

**Workaround Options**:
1. Build binaries locally and run tests without containers
2. Configure podman/docker to skip credential helper for public registries
3. Use plain `docker build` commands instead of compose
4. Add `--no-cache` or `--pull=never` flags

**Steps to Reproduce**:
```bash
cd test/e2e
podman-compose up -d
```

**Expected**: Services build and start successfully
**Actual**: Build fails with vault authentication timeout
close_reason: Added pull_policy to docker-compose.yml, comprehensive troubleshooting guide, and pre-pull-images.sh script

title: [P3] Create OpenAPI/Swagger specification for HTTP API
description:
## Problem
No OpenAPI/Swagger specification exists for the HTTP API:
- 531 handler patterns across codebase
- No API documentation beyond code comments
- Unclear API contracts for clients
- No automatic client generation

## Impact
- Difficult for clients to integrate

- API changes break clients without warning

## Evidence

- No openapi.yaml or swagger.json found
- README mentions HTTP API but no spec

## Recommended Fix
1. Generate OpenAPI 3.0 specification:
   - Use annotations or code generation
   - Document all endpoints
   - Include request/response schemas
   - Add authentication requirements
   - Version the spec

2. Set up tooling:
   - Swagger UI for interactive docs
   - Validation that code matches spec
   - Client SDK generation (Go, Python)
   - Breaking change detection

3. Host documentation:
   - Serve at /docs endpoint
   - Include in CI/CD pipeline
   - Update on every API change

Tools to consider:
- swaggo/swag (annotations)
- oapi-codegen (generate from spec)
- go-swagger (both directions)

## Estimated Effort
M (Medium) - 1-2 weeks

title: [P2] Decide on compilation v1 vs v2 migration path
description:
## Problem
Two compilation systems maintained in parallel:
- V1: Direct protoc execution (handlers.go:605-876, 270 lines)
- V2: Orchestrator-based with Docker (orchestrator/orchestrator.go)
- Feature flag: SPOKE_CODEGEN_VERSION controls which is used

## Impact
- Dual maintenance burden
- Inconsistent behavior between versions
- Technical debt accumulates
- Unclear which to use for new features

## Evidence
- handlers.go:89 - feature flag check
- compileGo() and compilePython() - 270 lines of v1 code
- orchestrator/ package - full v2 implementation
- No migration plan documented

## Recommended Fix
1. Document trade-offs of v1 vs v2:
   - V1: Simple, fast, requires protoc installed
   - V2: Isolated, reproducible, requires Docker
2. Choose default strategy:
   - Option A: Deprecate v1, migrate to v2
   - Option B: Keep v1 for simple cases, v2 for complex
   - Option C: Make v2 mandatory, remove v1
3. Create migration guide
4. Add deprecation warnings if removing v1
5. Set sunset date

## Estimated Effort
L (Large) - 1 week (including testing)

Need to determine which is the intended architecture.

title: [P3] Establish concurrency patterns and guidelines
description:
## Problem
Inconsistent concurrency patterns throughout codebase:
- 30+ `go func()` calls with varying safety patterns
- Some use context, some use context.Background(), some don't use context
- No standard goroutine lifecycle management
- No panic recovery in many goroutines
- WaitGroups used inconsistently

## Impact
- Potential goroutine leaks
- Unhandled panics crash process
- No graceful shutdown guarantee
- Memory leaks over time
- Race conditions possible

## Evidence
- handlers.go:359 - analytics without context deadline
- orchestrator.go:266, 300 - jobs without WaitGroup
- 29 mutex uses across 11 files (mostly correct)
- No documentation of thread-safety guarantees

## Recommended Fix
1. Create concurrency guidelines document:
   - When to use goroutines
   - Context usage (always from request, never Background)
   - Error handling patterns
   - Panic recovery requirements
   - Graceful shutdown patterns

2. Create helper utilities:
   - `SafeGo(ctx, fn)` - wrapper with panic recovery
   - `GracefulShutdown` - WaitGroup management
   - `WorkerPool` - bounded concurrency

3. Audit existing goroutines:
   - Add context to all
   - Add panic recovery
   - Ensure cleanup on shutdown

4. Add concurrency tests:
   - Race detection in CI
   - Load testing goroutine leaks

## Estimated Effort
L (Large) - 2-3 weeks

title: Migrate from MySQL to PostgreSQL with testcontainers-go
description:
**Goal**: Switch database from MySQL to PostgreSQL and use testcontainers-go for integration testing

**Motivation**:
- PostgreSQL is more standards-compliant than MySQL
- Better open-source ecosystem and licensing
- testcontainers-go enables proper integration testing with real database
- Will achieve 100% test coverage on verification.go

**Tasks**:
1. Update verification.go to use PostgreSQL-compatible SQL
   - Replace NOW() with CURRENT_TIMESTAMP or similar
   - Fix any MySQL-specific syntax
2. Update verification_test.go to use testcontainers-go
   - Spin up PostgreSQL container for tests
   - Run real integration tests against PostgreSQL
3. Update migrations to PostgreSQL syntax
   - Check migrations/010_plugin_marketplace.up.sql
   - Check migrations/011_plugin_verifications.up.sql
4. Update go.mod dependencies
   - Add github.com/testcontainers/testcontainers-go
   - Add github.com/lib/pq (PostgreSQL driver)
   - Remove github.com/go-sql-driver/mysql if not needed elsewhere
5. Update documentation and configuration
   - DATABASE_URL connection strings
   - Docker compose files
   - README instructions

**Benefits**:
- 100% test coverage on verification.go (currently 40%)
- Real database integration tests (not SQLite)
- More reliable CI/CD testing
- Better SQL standards compliance

**Current State**:
- verification.go uses MySQL syntax (NOW() function)
- Tests use SQLite in-memory (incompatible with MySQL syntax)
- 16/34 verification tests failing due to database incompatibility
close_reason: Successfully migrated from MySQL to PostgreSQL. All SQL queries converted (verification.go: 27 placeholders, migrations: 13 tables). Added testcontainers-go for real PostgreSQL integration tests. Migrations now PostgreSQL-compatible with BIGSERIAL, named constraints, and proper trigger syntax. Tests skip gracefully if Docker unavailable. Ready for 100% verification test coverage once Docker networking configured.

title: Breaking Change Detection
description:
Implement wire-level and source-level compatibility checking with multiple compatibility modes

**Priority:** P0 (Production blocker)
**Effort:** 6 weeks
**Timeline:** Q1 2026

**Requirements:**

**Wire-level compatibility checking:**
- Binary encoding analysis

- Type compatibility (int32 ↔ int64, etc.)

**Source-level compatibility checking:**
- Field additions/removals
- Field renames
- Package/namespace changes
- Import path changes

**Compatibility Modes:**
- BACKWARD: New schema can read old data
- FORWARD: Old schema can read new data
- FULL: Both backward and forward compatible
- NONE: No compatibility checking
- Per-module configuration

**Breaking Change Gates:**
- API endpoint to check compatibility before push
- CLI command: spoke check-compatibility
- CI/CD integration (GitHub Actions, GitLab CI)
- Approval workflow for breaking changes
- Override mechanism with justification

**Change Detection Algorithm:**
- Parse proto AST (already have parser)
- Build schema graph
- Compare field numbers, types, names
- Detect removed fields, changed types
- Generate human-readable diff

**API Examples:**
CLI: spoke push --check-compatibility-mode=FULL
API: POST /modules/{name}/versions/{version}/check-compatibility

**Impact:** Cannot prevent breaking changes, no schema governance

title: [P2] Refactor AST parser to use protoc descriptor API
description:
## Problem
pkg/api/protobuf/ast.go (1,028 lines) implements manual protobuf parsing:
- Custom tokenization and parsing
- Deep nesting (4-5 levels) in message/enum/service parsing
- Duplicated comment/directive parsing in 4 places
- Bug-prone and difficult to extend

## Impact
- Parser bugs affect schema validation
- Hard to add new protobuf features
- Maintenance burden high
- Likely missing edge cases

## Evidence
- ast.go: 1,028 lines of manual parser
- ast_test.go: 514 lines of tests
- Lines 798-856: deeply nested message parsing
- Lines 886-929: duplicated enum parsing logic

## Recommended Fix
Consider alternatives:
1. Use protoc descriptor API:
   - Parse to FileDescriptorSet
   - Extract AST from descriptors
2. Use buf libraries:
   - Already integrated (buf_integration_test.go)
   - Well-tested, feature-complete
3. Hybrid approach:
   - Keep custom parser for directives
   - Use protoc for proto syntax

Benefits:
- Reduce code by 500+ lines
- Better edge case handling
- Official protobuf support
- Easier to maintain

## Estimated Effort
L (Large) - 1-2 weeks

title: [P1] Consolidate 4 different Storage interfaces
description:
## Problem
Found 4 different Storage interfaces across packages:
1. pkg/api/types.go:123 - `Storage` interface
2. pkg/storage/interfaces.go:12 - `StorageV2` interface  
3. pkg/search/indexer.go:21 - `StorageReader` interface
4. pkg/marketplace/storage.go:9 - `Storage` interface

## Impact
- Unclear which interface to implement
- Forces adapter proliferation
- Breaks interface segregation
- Difficult to add storage backends
- Only 2 files import pkg/api (suggests package isolation issues)

## Evidence
- grep shows 4 distinct Storage interface definitions
- PostgresStorage implements both Storage and StorageV2
- Migration incomplete with 8 TODOs in postgres.go

## Recommended Fix
1. Define single canonical interface in pkg/storage/interfaces.go
2. Use interface composition for specialized needs:
   - StorageReader (read-only operations)
   - StorageWriter (write operations)
   - StorageAdmin (admin operations)
3. Deprecate old interfaces
4. Migrate all implementations to new structure

## Estimated Effort
L (Large) - 3-4 days
